results.name: Least splitter of s(n) and s(n+1), where s(n) = 1/sqrt(1) + 1/sqrt(2) + ... + 1/sqrt(n).
comment: Suppose that x < y.  The least splitter of x and y is introduced at A227631 as the least positive integer d such that x <= c/d < y for some integer c; the number c/d is called the least splitting rational of x and y.
The positions of 1 in this sequences (indicating those least splitting rationals of s(n) and s(n+1) which are integers) are given by A186351.
link: Clark Kimberling, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
example: The denominators (A227687) and numerators (A227688) can be read from these chains:
mathematica: r[x_, y_] := Module[{c, d}, d = NestWhile[#1 + 1 &, 1, ! (c = Ceiling[#1 x - 1]) < Ceiling[#1 y] - 1 &]; (c + 1)/d];
